Emotions run pretty high in the build up to an election, fights break out over which candidate people support (this is just anecdotal, I have no specific example of this), men and women cry when their president is assassinated etc etc etc.
 
 You don't find this sort of hero worship in places like the UK or Canada. We all realise that some other arrogant self-centred twit has come to power, and hope that things don't get too much worse during their reign.

 I don't wish Obama ill. I do hope he's a good president, and hope he does well. But whether he leads well or not remains to be seen, to say the least, and I'm not interested in Camelot or the hero-worship that's going on. Yes, I'm absolutely cynical--sorry, but Obama is a politician, just as McCain was. I'm not interested in a rock star for president, and I'm not going to give Obama the benefit of the doubt automatically any more than I would with any candidate. He's going to have to prove himself. He'll likely do better than Bush, because that doesn't take much, but if that's the extent of our standards and expectations then we're all in trouble! A presidential election isn't a source of joy to me--it's just an election, pure and simple.

Being a hard-nosed liberal, I've never found Obama to be a messiah.
 
 Truth be told, the idea of a man who can actually speak and communicate well in English, who doesn't speak gibberish, does make him appear to be a messiah when you contrast him with George W. Bush.
Given the way economies work, a bit of mindless optimism might do the US (and indeed the world for that matter) a power of good.

What got me excited last night was for the first time in so long I saw hope in so many faces. That much hope, that much goodwill is a gift. 
 
 I voted for Obama but he was never my number one choice, I was never that excited about him. But after watching him, and more importantly seeing/reading people's reactions to his win - not just here, but around the globe, I think he has the potential to mend the divisions in our country. If he really, truly does what he says he will - listen to his opposition, inspire us to find our common ground and work together - just THAT alone would be amazing. I have spent the last 8 years feeling invisible to my government. I heard in Governer Palin's first speach at the RNC that I was to her as well. I hope Obama won't do that to conservatives. He says he won't. For now I am going to feel a bit of that hope and take him at his word.

I've never been that interested in my own election but i watched your whole election from start to finish. I can hardly recall many moments when i was more moved by society.
 
 I'm not American, but boy george was i proud of your people and your country yesterday. Not just for the result, but for the movement itself.
 I have never seen a nation, so patriotic and so committed to a cause as i have witnessed on both sides last night.
 The sadness of the republicans and the most dignified, humbled concession speech I've ever heard coupled with the overwhelming tears of joy from the democrats was truly touching. All of you made an impact.
 
 Regardless weather your candidate won or not, yesterday you made history, your country and its citizens (both sides) moved and inspired the whole world. It was a profound moment in time.
 
 Congratulations President-Elect Barack Obama, i hope you lead your magnificent country with all that the people aspire, encompass and hope.

We have had enough, the world has had enough! It is time we reach out with a hand of friendship to our fellow man and show the world that the american dream does still exist! That we are a people who love one another and we cant be divided by our petty differences anymore. 
 
 Maybe we can now have true civil rights now that the senate, house, and executive branch are liberal and open minded. And hopefully soon the judicial branch as well. Maybe just maybe not jsut gays but other minorities can get the rights they finally deserve free of discrimination.

 Anyway, Obama is a politician, not a messiah. He's already demonstrated he's not going to pull people together by putting Rahm Emmanuel as his chief of Staff. That's like Bush giving the job to Karl Rove, so already he's done something he knew would be divisive. There's no reason (other than the words of a politician to get elected, big whoop) to think it won't be bidness as usual in Washington.

You've mentioned that more than once now. I'll bite ... what on earth is it she said that makes you think she meant that she doesn't care about you?

 
 Her snide comments about Obama's activities as a community organizer in Chicago (I know they weren't direct - it was inferred). The dismassal was a slap in the face of every citizen who lives in inner-city urban communities. She never seemed to comprehend that this country is not just peopled with small-town, soccer moms. She certainly never demonstrated that she had the vision to be able to handle being a leader in a diverse world. You have no idea how that woman infuriates me. McCain never did. Just her. 
 
 
Anyway, Obama is a politician, not a messiah. He's already demonstrated he's not going to pull people together by putting Rahm Emmanuel as his chief of Staff. That's like Bush giving the job to Karl Rove, so already he's done something he knew would be divisive. There's no reason (other than the words of a politician to get elected, big whoop) to think it won't be bidness as usual in Washington.

 
 I never saw Obama as any kind of messiah. But I am excited by people's response to him - and if he walks his talk I believe he has the potential to truly unite folks. But, you are right, first he has to walk the talk. 
 
 Understand that this is not why I voted for him. I voted for him because I agreed with his stand on more of the issues than I did McCain. And I also was not going to contribute to getting Palin anywhere near the white house. These thoughts have come to me since election night, after seeing people respond and hearing his speach in Grant Park.
